data.event: The first post office in the area was named Freedom, established in 1858.
The name was changed to Lancaster in 1866 and to Junction City in 1872.
About 1852 or 1853, a man named Woody started a "house of entertainment" (aka a roadhouse) at this locale, which he named "Woodyville".
The sawmill was still operating in 1861 and likely longer.

The Great Flood of 1862 changed the course of the river, leaving the town too far from the main channel, however, and the Oregon and California Railroad bypassed Lancaster, so Junction City became the more important community.
